ingestedContentSummary.description: When I started out as a consultant back in the stone age (2020), I was struck by how intransparent this industry was.
ingestedContentSummary.fullText: When I started out as a consultant back in the stone age (2020), I was struck by how intransparent this industry was. Want to download standards? Please pay money for a PDF. Need templates? Purchase them from consultants. Have questions? Ask a consultant, get billed by the hour. I thought this sucked. Gatekeepers in this industry were optimizing for their own, short-term gains, while prohibiting advancement of the field as a whole. I thought I could make a change, and that was how OpenRegulatory was born. I thought: As long as I can be profitable as a consultant, I can give away lots of stuff for free. That would enable startups who don’t have any funds to pay me to get their documentation done by themselves. Since then, OpenRegulatory even more free templates , and nowadays they are so complete that you can essentially do an entire medical device submission by yourself, for free! That’s amazing, and I’ve witnessed many startups enter the market who otherwise wouldn’t have been able to, because they built their company with their own savings, and paying a consultant was not feasible. And, on the other side, I’ve heard from multiple Notified Bodies that they see many submissions based on the OpenRegulatory templates, and they generally like those, because they tend to be quite complete, yet also not exceedingly long. That’s awesome! In 2022, we took that even further by offering our own QMS software, Formwork . The thinking here was quite the same: If we manage to make this profitable, let’s give away as much as we can for free. That’s how the Formwork Community Edition came to be, which (still) is probably the only, 100% free QMS software for document management out there. Unlimited users, too! This was another stepping stone in supporting those bootstrapped startups, where 3 dudes or dudesses are sitting in a cold garage, furiously hacking away on their medical device prototype, willing to put in grueling hours and suffer unlimited pain, because they’re creating their MDR documentation by themselves. Mad props. Still, there was a wrinkle: To make things profitable, we had to price the paid versions of Formwork quite highly: 499€ or 799€ per month. Now - this actually isn’t a high price if you compare us to other QMS software providers. Those typically have higher prices, multi-year contracts, limited user seats and no data export (good luck with the lock-in). So, if you compare Formwork to those, Formwork wins easily, and many companies are slowly realizing that, too. I regularly talk to companies who reach out whether they can migrate to Formwork to save money, and they’re tired of dealing with their shady QMS salespeople. So Formwork is cool, and the price point is great. But here’s the problem: For the three dudes in the garage, 499€ per month is not great. And those dudes are not comparing Formwork to other QMS software, they’re comparing it to generic software which might do the job, but is priced much lower: Software like Google Drive and Confluence ( ugh ). What usually happens next? I’ve seen this time and time again: The three dudes choose Confluence. Initially, they would be happy with their choice. But, a few months down the line, preparing their audit submission, the pain would start. Creating and maintaining regulatory documentation in a generic tool which is not purpose-built is, at minimum, a full-time regulatory job. But, in reality, it’s much worse than that: Because it was not purpose-built, it has evolved into a gigantic mess of epic proportions, resembling a “Frankenstein”-like monster where different systems, plugins and custom scripts have been stitched together in a very broken way. And the output still sucks, because essential stuff (e.g. traceability) is missing. So choosing Confluence, or Google Drive, or Notion usually ends up spawning this sort of Zombie-like apocalypse in your startup. Not great. But even worse, the founders only realize this when it’s too late. They’ve been using Confluence for a long time, preparing their audit submission, and only now realize that it’s a huge mess. This is a lose-lose situation, because your options are: And the root case was somewhat our fault, because Formwork was too expensive for the three dudes in the garage. That’s why, today, we’re introducing Formwork Starter: Everything in Formwork, at a much lower price, so that the three dudes in the garage no longer choose Confluence. Formwork Starter is, quite literally, our full Formwork software at a fraction of its price. No strings attached! It’s our offer to early-stage startups so that they don’t screw up by choosing Confluence. We don’t like limiting user seats or storage, because both things lead to weird workarounds (shared user accounts etc.) and are shady anyway. That’s why we base this offer on a trust-based approach which looks at your company’s situation. Specifically, to qualify for Formwork Starter, your company should have: .. and they need to be sitting in a garage. Just kidding. But the prior three points still stand. And once you have funding or revenue, simply reach out to us to upgrade to the normal price. So now, there’s really nothing holding you back from choosing Formwork for your medical device startup. Give it a try! For now, we’re testing Formwork Starter with a limited number of customers. Hit the “Contact us” button on the Formwork page to reach out if you’re interested!
ingestedContentSummary.title: Launching Formwork Starter: 49€ For QMS Software And Requirements Management

message.text:
eQMS Software for only 49€ / month? So far, this didn't exist. Today, it does - we're launching Formwork Starter.

When I started out as a consultant back in the stone age (2020), I was struck by how intransparent this industry was.

Want to download standards? Please pay money for a PDF. Need templates? Purchase them from consultants. Have questions? Ask a consultant, get billed by the hour.

I thought this sucked.

Gatekeepers in this industry were optimizing for their own, short-term gains, while prohibiting advancement of the field as a whole.

I thought I could make a change, and that was how OpenRegulatory was born. I thought: As long as I can be profitable as a consultant, I can give away lots of stuff for free. That would enable startups who don’t have any funds to pay me to get their documentation done by themselves.

So I started writing and publishing our MDR QMS + Techdoc templates for free, and that's how we got somewhat famous.

The whole mission of OpenRegulatory can be summarized as "enabling three dudes in a garage to bring their medical device to market". Those three dudes (or dudesses!) generally don't have a lot of money, so our free templates already propelled them very far towards market entry.

There's one wrinkle though: QMS software. QMS software has huge leverage in saving you lots of time due to automation - but it's not available to the three dudes in the garage, because QMS software has historically been very expensive. Even our own! Formwork for startups is priced at 499€ / month, cheaper than almost everyone, yet too expensive for the garage dudes.

Until today.

Nowadays, Formwork is profitable, so I'm free to take whatever measures are necessary to prevent the Three Garage Dudes from choosing generic tools like Jira / Confluence, because those are "cheaper".

Here's the reason: I hate Confluence, and I hate Jira.

That's why, right now, we're launching Formwork Starter to convince people to not choose Jira.

If your company has:
- No funding yet (private / public)
- No revenue
- 3 people or less working in it full-time, regardless of salary.

.. then we'll give you Formwork for 49€ / month, until any of those criteria change for your company. All features, no strings attached. Export your data any time.

Learn more (and don't choose Jira):
https://lnkd.in/d9XWNh2N

ingestedContentSummary.description: akina develops Physiotherapy software for patients to reduce pain and improve mobility. Using Formwork, they received their QMS certification by DQS, a Notified Body in Germany, in August 2023. It only took them 7 months from contacting DQS to getting...
ingestedContentSummary.title: Formwork

message.text:
BerlinCert, a Notified Body, recently issued their first MDR product certificate - and it was for a submission created with our eQMS software, Formwork.

It's hard to overstate how cool this is: At the very least, it's another data point that suggests that Formwork might be *the* fastest way to create your (compliant!) technical documentation when going for MDR certification.

When we started developing eQMS software 4 years ago, we wanted to make a change: Our goal was to enable medical software startups (like yours?) to reap all the benefits of eQMS software automation (faster submissions!) without incurring any of the downsides: Shady pricing models, multi-year contracts and locked-in data.

That's what lead us to Formwork: The only eQMS software with monthly, transparent pricing, unlimited user accounts und zero lock-in.

And today, with BerlinCert's first product certificate, we have another piece of evidence to prove that our approach works.

And that's in addition to multiple QMS audits which customers have already passed with Formwork!

If you're a startup and want to bring a medical device to market in the most efficient way possible.. check out Formwork:

https://lnkd.in/gJDW_aWT

Also: We're launching a 49€ / month pricing tier for very-early-stage startups (because I hate Jira). Stay tuned! :)

ingestedContentSummary.description: Digital Health Jobs is a job board for companies which are currently hiring people in Digital Health, from startups to enterprises.
ingestedContentSummary.title: Digital Health Jobs

message.text:
Are you looking for a job in digital health? Or is your company hiring?

Last year, we launched Digital Health Jobs, a job board for digital health jobs. Since then, 100+ jobs have been added. It kind of fell asleep for a while as we were distracted with building other cool stuff (more on that next week!).

But, for now, we're reviving Digital Health jobs. Even though the job market isn't as good as it was in the past, there are still many companies out there who are hiring.

Job posts are still free (for now), so definitely add yours if you're hiring, too!

Check it out here:
https://lnkd.in/e7aue_xN

commentary.text: Milano Fili Thanks for your kind words! Wishing you as little regulatory pain as possible at Huma, too, although what you're doing (and at the scale you're doing it) definitely has a high risk of incurring all sorts of regulatory pain, haha.. still, keep it up!
Laura Irwin Rossing Thanks so much! 🙂
Arnesh Kumar Issar Hahaha yes, thanks for your kind words!

Hi Peter, good questions! We provide procedures for all the standards your mentioned. In fact, our templates for those are free, you can even find them on our website! They're also included in our eQMS, too, of course.

Signatures are part 11 compliant.

Multiple startups have passed EU MDR audits with Formwork 🙂

Dirk Mueller, Ph.D, MBA that's what many regulatory people say, but I strongly disagree with that. Some ideas:

- How many customers of ChatGPT base their purchasing decision on whether it has a CE label? I'd argue the answer is "no one".

- Medical devices: How many doctors even know what a CE label means? Hardly any. So this doesn't influence purchasing decision on their side.

- Historically speaking, when has stricter regulation *ever* lead to some sort of competitive advantage? Let's see.. GDPR.. nope. Medical devices (MDR).. nope. Genuinely curious, I don't know of any examples.

So it begins - I expect more tech startups to leave Europe once the AI Act comes into effect. It's quite ironic that even the EU AI Office chooses US-based software nowadays (Webex), haha.. I mean, if this would truly be about EU-based innovation, you could have self-hosted Jitsi or something like that
This looks awesome. Like University, except that you're working on cool stuff. If I'd be less neurotic about quietness, I'd be in! 😄
Laura Irwin Rossing thanks so much! And thanks for using it! 🙂
Awesome, thanks so much for your kind words! :)
Erik Marzaganov awesome! Let me know if/when they're ready! :)
Thanks for sharing, very.. decent of you! 😁
Yes, true, I was referring to SaMD. Here's a data point: ~5 employees, class IIa SaMD, MDR QMS + Techdoc Audit, 22k€.

Yes, I'm sure. The general range for startups we've talked to or are working with is between 20-80k€, with the median at around 50k€ (multiple data points).

Would be interesting to hear which Notified Body you had (I usually bet on BSI when I hear those things and, more often than not, that bet is correct).
